Odetta's appearance on
Friday night, April 21, and
the annual IFC Spring
Formal on Saturday night
Will highlight this year's
IFC weekend.
The tickets for the Odetta
concert are $2.00, $2.25, and
$2.50 and are available at Levering Hall YMCA. Odetta is being
Jointly sponsored by the Levering YMCA and the IFC.
The IFC Formal which is being
held at the Blue Crest North
Ballroom will feature the King
Guard Orchestra. This orchestra has played under the name
Of Lester Lanin and consists of
seventeen pieces and a vocalist.
Popular Folksing-er
Odetta, a popular folksinger,
has appeared in numerous festivals and concerts and has been
featured on many television and
radio programs, including the
Belafonte Spectacular, the Ed
Sullivan Show, and the Ernie
Ford Show.
She has also appeared in concerts at Carnegie Hall and Town
Hall in New York. Recently she
had a supporting role in the
movie, "Sanctuary."
Odetta is noted for her rich
and powerful voice as well as
for the "emotional immediacy
of her singing."
Says Dougherty
According to Frank Dougherty,
President of the IFC, this year's
formal will feature service at all
of the tables by waiters. Set-ups,
Potato chips, pretzels, will all be
served free of charge.
The tables for the dance will
be arranged in "cabaret style"
complete with linen and glassware. Free parking will be available.
A highlight of the IFC Formal
Will be the awarding of keys
and the presentation of the gavel
to the new president of the IFC.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, APRIL 14, 1961

Call To Peace Corps Proclaimed Debate,Scandals Liven
Applications Available t Levering SC Election Campaigns
Th41 week the men of Johns
Hopkins heard the call to duty
as the Peace Corps program finally hit Levering Hall, and applications became available in
the YMCA office.
The Kennedy Administration's
pet project was initiated last
February, when Sargent Shriver,
the Corps' director, submitted a
memorandum to his brother-inlaw, the President. Mr. Shriver's
report calls for an organization

of young college graduates who
will _go abroad to teach, participate in health, agricultural,
and industrial projects, and work
in government administration.
The volunteers will be unpaid
and will not be exempt from tile
draft.
Requirements
Applicants for service in the
Corps, says the application,
"should have technical ability,
physical stamina and emotional

Travel Sales Representative

Agency offering a comprehensive Student Travel Program. Here is a unique opportunity for an active,
enthusiastic student or faculty member to earn considerable remuneration and valuable foreign travel
benefits. Apply by letter, giving full particulars and
details of your sales potential to

stability. They must be able to
adapt themselves to an unfamiliar way of-life and to work overseas with peoples of all colors,
religions, races, and cultures.
Many volunteers will work and
live apart from other Americans.
Proficiency in a language other
than English will often be necessary. The usual length of service will be two years."
Hopkins reaction to the Peace
Corps idea was typified by a
Junior electrical engineering student who said, "It's a good idea.
For certain dedicated individuals
this presents an excellent and
organized opportunity. If I
weren't engaged, I might be
interested." Another
Junior,
Majoring in English, commented
that "the Peace Corps is just
another name for the WPA. You
know—Grab your pick and see
the world."
From the body of undergraduates in the biological sciences
came two comments, both from
Sophomores; "Are you out of
your mind?" and "Anything
that comes out of it will be an
improvement over what we
have."

unopposed.
Deadline Extensions
A second cause for complaint
was the extension of the' deadline for student council representatives. This deadline did
not extend to class officers. Thus
while petitions for class officers
were refused after the original
deadline of March 22 petitions
for student Council representatives were accepted until April
4th.
Yet another problem has
arisen over the fact that two
students ran unopposed for class
officers. Both of these boys are
members of Phi Ep and in both
cases the petitions of candidates
opposing them were 'refused.
However, in one case the opposition candidate did not have a
2.3 average, and in the second
case the candidate's petition was
turned in late. As was pointed
out above, in both of these cases
the letter of the law was observed.
General Irregularities
Two other irregularities developed in the elections concernfling Phi Ep. The first of these

was a series of posters put up
around school urging the students to vote against candidates
who were members of Phi Ep.
Following this incident two
members of Phi Sig, both of
whom were candidates for office were accused of putting
these signs up. However, to the
certain knowledge of this reporter neither of these boys was
involved.
A, B, C, D...
The final so-called scandal
occured during the elections for
freshman offices in the fall. At
this time the names on the ballot were listed out of alphabetical
order with members of Phi Ep
being listed first in some instances.
Concerning this matter David
Adams, former president of the
SC, could only state that "I
hope the ballots for this election
are in alphabetical order."
Coincidence
Assaying the entire situation,
it is evident that at this date
no actual irregularities have been
discovered. If some facts of the
election, especially those concerning Phi Ep and her alleged
control of the election committee, seem strange, we can only
ascribe it to coincidence.

Nicholas Traces Policy Kaufman Stopped Again By Vayne
Of Britain Toward U.S. From Selling Socialist Magazine
Dr. Herbert Nicholas,. Fellow
of New College, Oxford, delivered
the 62nd of the annual Albert
Shaw Lectures this week.
In his first lecture Dr. Nicholas
traced the evolution of British
Post war policy towards the
United States. After World War
Dr. Nicholas stated, British
Policy had two main objectives.
The first of these was "to
secure American aid in economic
reconstruction." The second was
to prevent a recurrance of the
disasterous attitude of isolationism into which the United States
had fallen following World War
I. In securing these objectives
Great Britain was relatively successful.
However, as Dr. Nicholas
Pointed out in his second lecture, the British were also faced
With a third serious problem.
Britain could no longer maintain
her world-wide military cornMitments.
Drawing attention to the de-

Engineering Plan
Joins Medicine
In Graduate Work
A new graduate curriculum
Which integrates the engineering
and medical sciences will be
Initiated next September.
The new program, to be known
as "bio-medical engineering," is
the first of its kind in the country. Students will study for a
doctorate and will take courses
at both Homewood and the
School of Medicine.
The purpose of the new course
is to train students in advanced
engineering subjects of particular pertinence to research in
biological systems and to offer
Systematic study in how the
Principles of physical and engineering science apply to biological systems.
A great impetus has been
!Placed on applying many of
these physical principles common
to engineering design and practice to the medical sciences.
Much work has already been
done in this line, but not on the
student level.
Two other institutions, Rochester and Pennsylvania, will institute similar progi•ams and the
three universities will cooperate
extensively.
Professor James F. Bell, Associate professor of solid mechanics, and Dr. Samuel A. Talbot,
associate professor of medicine,
have collaborated in developing
the program.
Applications for admission to
the program should be .made
through the School of Engineering.

DR. FROOD'S THOUGHT FOR THE DAY:

Dear Dr. Frood: I just can't seem to
get in step with the rest of the students
here. They enjoy parties, dancing, folk
singing and dating. None of these
things interest me at all. Am I behind
the times or what?
Left Out
DEAR LEFT: You're in the right times;
you're just one of our squares.

Dear Dr. Frood: I have a confession.
All my life I have been trying to
learn how to whistle. I just can't.
Please, will you tell me how to
whistle?
Puckered
DEAR PUCKERED: Watch the birds.

Notice how they gather a pocket of
air deep within the breast, then
push thin jets of this air into the
throat, through the larynx, up and
around the curled tongue, and then
bounce the air from the roof of the
mouth out through the teeth (which
act like the keyboard on a piano).
Practice this. In no time your
friends will be amazed at the beautiful, warbly trills that flow from
your beak..,

Let Them Eat Cake
One begins to wonder if A. Robert Kaufman, Baltimore's omnipresent Socialist, will ever give up in his fight
to get his paper, the Young Socialist, sold on campus at
the Hopkins Bookstore. For almost a year he's been
trying. Most recently, the excuse offered by the Bookstore
for its refusal to handle Kaufman's paper, is that the Store
does not handle newspapers, Socialist or otherwise.
Just the other day, however, Kaufman again spoke
to Mr. Vayne, the Bookstore Manager, and also to WesleY
Taylor, Plant Manager, in an effort to have put on sale
in the Bookstore, the Young Socialist and two other Leftist
periodicals, the Militant and the International Socialist
Review. This time he was told "no" on the first two, but
"yes" on the International Socialist Review if this could
be furnished to the store through its usual distributor, the
Maryland News Company. According to Kaufman, this
is tantamount to refusing all three publications, because
6 the Maryland News Company doesn't handle the International Socialist Review.
Mr. Kaufman is an obnoxious person to many people
and it would be quite understandable if the Bookstore
decided not to sell his Socialist publications purely because
of Kaufman. But we have a hunch that the refusal comes
because of the contents of the Young Socialist and the
other two periodicals. And if this is so, then the Bookstore should say so, and prepare to defend itself against
the charge that the college student has a right to be
exposed to all points of view, even the most unpopular
kind espoused by Kaufman.
There were, we understand, forces in the administration, which disapproved when the YMCA presented a
high-ranking Communist official at one of its Cosmopolitan Club meetings. But the man came, spoke his piece,
and left with no great harm being done. The speech was
a poor one; not even the most liberal elements of those
attending were impressed.

By what means is this object
attainable?
Evidently by one
or two only: Either the existence
of the same passion or interest
in a majority at the same time
must be prevented, to the majority, having such co-existent
pa&sion or interest, must be rendered, by their numbers and
local situation, unable to concert
and carry into effect schemes of
oppression. If the impulse and
the opportunity be suffered to
coincide, we well know that
neither moral nor religious motives can be relied on as an
adequate control.
—James Madison

BOOM!
Today,foregoing levity,let us turn our keen young minds to the
No. 1 problem facing American colleges today: the population
explosion. Only last week four people exploded in Cleveland,
Ohio—one of them while carrying a plate of soup. In case you're
thinking Such a thing couldn't happen anywhere but in Cleveland, let me tell you there were also two other cases last week—
a 45 year old man in Provo, Utah, and a 19 year old girl in
Bangor, Maine—and in addition there was a near-miss in
Klamath Falls, Oregon—an eight year old boy who was saved
only by the quick thinking of his cat Walter who pushed the
phone off the hook with his muzzle and dialled the department
of weights and measures. (It would perhaps have made more
sense for Walter to dial the fire department, but one can hardly
expect a cat to summon a fire engine which is followed by a
Dalmatian, can one?)

I bring up the population explosion not to alarm yoti; for I
feel certain that science will ultimately solve the problem. After
all, has not science in recent years brought us such marvels as
the transistor, the computer, the bevatron, and the Marlboro
filter? Oh, what a saga of science was the discovery of the
Marlboro filter! Oh, what a heart-rending epic of endless trial
and error, of dedication and perseverance! And,in the end, what
a triumph it was when the Marlboro scientists after years of
testing and discarding one filter material after another—iron,
nickel, lead, tin, antimony,sponge cake—finally emerged, tired
but happy, from their laboratory, carrying in their hands the
perfect filter cigarette! What rejoicing there was that day!
Indeed,what rejoicing there still is whenever we light a Marlboro
and settle back and enjoy that full-flavored smoke which comes
to us in soft pack or flip-top box at tobacco counters in all
fifty states and Cleveland!
Yes,science will ultimately solve the problems rising out of the
population explosion, but in the meantime the problems hang
heavy over America's colleges. This year will bring history's
greatest rush of high school graduates. Where will we find classrooms and teachers for this gigantic new influx?
Well sir,some say the answer is to adopt the trimester system.
This system, now in use at many colleges, eliminates summer
vacations, has three semesters per annum instead of two, and
compresses a four year course into three years.
This is good,but is it good enough? Even under the trimester
system the student has occasional days off. Moreover his nights
are utterly wasted in sleeping. Is this the kind of all-out attack
that is indicated?
I say no. I say desperate problems call for desperate remedies.'I say that partial measures will not solve this crisis. I say
we must do no less than go to school every single day of the
year. But that is not all. I say we must go to school 24 hours
of every day!
The benefits of such a program are, of course, obvious. First
of all, the classroom shortage will immediately disappear because all the dormitories can be converted into classrooms.
Second,the teacher shortage will immediately disappear because
all the night watchmen can be put to work teaching calculus
and Middle English poetry. And finally, overcrowding will
immediately disappear because everyone will quit school.
Any further questions?
ED 1961 Max Shulman

relay operations. All together, this interconnecting equipment makes up the heart of what

The D.S.R.C. this week held an
extended debate on whether or
not to purchase laundry baskets
for the dormitory laundry.
Representative Fred Schermaker stated that he had received numerous requests for
such baskets "so that you don't
have to drag your clothes across
the floor." It was further pointed out that the baskets would
only cost 59 cents a piece.
A second representative then
inquired why "if these people are
so concerned, they don't invest
59 cents and buy it themselves."
It was finally decided that the
D.S.R.C. would purchase one
basket. This decision was also
objected to on the grounds that
"only one basket will cause friction."

unity against the administration.
But Ricci was later forced to
consider the realities of the situation and modify his stand.
In the meantime, Abernethy
consistently tried to present a
conservative platform aimed at

government by both the faculty
and administration.

Reasonable Approach
In general, one had the feeling
that the first candidate to be
asked a question chose the most
reasonable approach, and the
second candidate was forced to
somehow modify this view.
The most apparent and probably the most real difference between the two candidates occured
over the problem of the SAC.
This issue was visibly embarrassing to Ricci who was forced to
defend all aspects of the SAC
because he is currently a junior
member of the Commission.
`Morrill's Pet'
At the same time Ricci accurately stated that the SAC was
"Morrill's pet" and that the
Student Council could do nothing
about this.
But when Abernethy mentioned some of the controversial
policies of the SAC, Ricci was
forced by his position into defending the almost indefensible.
But the overall debate was
basically a failure. Anyone could

have accurately written the debate out beforehand with the exception of several of Ricci's
statements. 'All of the standard
student government problems
were discussed in their traditional style with most of the
traditional answers being given
by one candidate or the other.
New Suggestion
Perhaps the only really new
suggestion made came at the
very end of the debate. Abernethy suggested that public information campaign be .initiated
educating the dormitory residents on the problem of vandalism. As Abernethy pointed out
the $20,000 spent each year on
vandalism and destruction in the

dorms could be put to much
better use elsewhere.
Abernethy went on to state
that proctors were no solution to
the problem and their presence
in the dorm might even spur new
damage as a form of student
protest.
Valid Conclusion
It is almost impossible to reach
any valid conclusion on the basis
of this one debate. However, it is
fairly safe to make the following
statements:
Ricci was more willing to stick
his neck out if he thinks it may
win him some votes.
There was really not much
visible difference between the
candidates or their platforms.

On Tuesday the varsity easily

singles matches, and two of the
three doubles, the Jays upped
their season record to 2-1, and to
2-0, in Mason-Dixon play. Winners for the Blue were Baron,
Brenner, Cameron, Urner, and
Farnham in singles, and UrnerBaron, and Brenner-Cameron in
doubles. Mel Lurie, in singles,
and substitutes Herb Dorsey and
Larry Garceau in doubles. were
the only people to drop points
in the match.

By IRV NATHAN
Hopkins varsity lacrosse squad,
now rated the logical favorite
for national lacrosse honors,
comes face to face with its first
large stumbling block of the
young campaign tomorrow when
it visits the University of Virginia at Charlottesville.
Off recent performances of the
top rated stick contingents in the
country, collegiate coaches have
come out with what may be
nothing more than a psychological maneuver in acclaiming the
Blue Jays the likely first place
choice. Last week's showing
against Princeton did little to
dissuade these "experts," led by
Navy's head coach Bill Bilder
back.
Playing before a screaming
throng of 2,500 partisan fans,
the Blue Jay ten demolished last
year's Ivy League champions
Princeton, 19-6, last Saturday at
Homewood. But although Hopkins exhibited tremendous power
in all areas and Coach Bob Scott
had to empty his bench to keep
the score down, there were some
mighty uneasy moments in the
first quarter for Hopkins backers.
The Jays could score but once
in the initial quarter and actually trailed 1-0 at the end of 13.35
of that period. A devestating attack, led by Roy Mayne, Jimmy
Ives, and Jerry Schmidt, soon
disspelled the fears of the crowd.
After 2.40 of the second quarter,
the score had catapulted to 5-1,
and the Blue Jays were never
headed from that point.
Howard Krongard, a traduate
of Baltimore City College, was
nothing short of spectacular in
the goal for Princeton until he
got the urge to roam and found
himself out of position on several crucial occasions. No other
Tiger distinguished himself as
the six tallies were distributed
among six Princeton stickers.

Hopkins, on the other hand,
turned in several standout performances. Mayne, a continuously improving attacker, fired six
goals and had three assists.
Schmidt assisted four times
while finding time to score twice.
And Ives, pitted in a gigantic
battle with Tim Lowery for the
third starting spot on attack,
poured in four goals and assisted twice.
Tom Biddison and Skippy Leet
scored two goals apiece to augment the prolific attack. Dick
Webster, turning in a stickout
performance, Henry ciccarone,
and Phil Sutley also chalked up
goals on the scoreboard. Sutley's
shot, the last of the day, came
after a run which carried him
the length of the field to Princeton's nets.

Statistics-wise, Hopkins again
came out the certain victor. The
Blue Jays rifled seventy-five
shots compared to thirty-seven
by the Tigers. Hopkins also led
in penalties 7-6. In the nets,
Princeton's Krongard saved 21
shots while Hopkins goalies, Jim
Greenwood and Mal Buchner,
saved a total of nine.
Virginia was not so fortunate
this past weekend as the Cavahers succumed to Maryland's
heavy attack, 14-8. The game
even Virginia's seasonal log off
at 1-1 and the Southerners
would like nothing better than
to impress stick followers at
Hopkins' expense tomorrow.
The Cavalier's biggest asset is
their attack unit, though this
fact was not prevalent last week.

Hopkins Batting Fails
Squad In 2 Contests
"The pitching is there." That's
the verdict from Hopkins baseball coach Ross Sachs after an
opening week in which he saw
his charges go down three times
—each time rebounding in a
more determined fashion from
the sting of defeat. Especially
satisfying was the come-back
performance of Soph hurler Stan
Mazanek who twirled the last
seven innings of no-hit, no-run
ball in the Jays' third loss of
the week, a 4-2 loss to RandolphMacon.
However, the big obstacle to
victory remained hitting. "We
can count on good pitching and
defense has been adequate. But
when we are going to begin to
win depends on when we start
to hit," said Sachs.
Bay State Men
Coach Sachs, during the first
week's activity also received
some fine mound-work in the
6-3 12 inning loss to MIT from
pitchers Koslowski and Kotowski,
two fellows who sound like members of an old vaudeville juggling act, but who combined for
seven shut-out innings before the
Bay State men pushed across
the winning three in the twelfth.
But the big news on the Homewood diamond was made by
Mazanek.
The promising Soph bounced
back from his portion of the
15-0 thumping Loyola administered to the Jays on opening day
to spin a nifty three hitter,

with all three safeties coming
in the first two innings. Mazanek
gave up all four runs in the first
on an error, three walks, and two
singles.
A single followed in the next
inning, but after that Mazanek
was as tough as Hopkins cafeteria meat for the Randolph
Macon batters. He walked only
one man the rest of the way.
Hopkins picked up two runs in
the sixth without a base-hit.
Catcher Bob Meyers 4th inning
single was the lone safety in a
long afternoon for Hopkins batters.
Long Afternoons
In fact, it's been a series of
long afternoons for Hopkins batters who have averaged but four
hits per game to date. Catcher
Meyers is far out in front with
four hits in twelve at bats for
a .333 mark. Meyers' fine work
behind the mask, however was
what drew the praises from HopRoss
mentor
kins' baseball
Sachs. Said Coach Sachs: "Bob
threw out one runner apiece
against Loyola and MIT. Nobody's running on him. This adds
to the confidence of our pitchers."
Coach Sachs felt the defensive
work of outfielder Mary Jones
and Leon Poffenberger also
merited special praise. Jones
contributed a sparkling diving
catch against Randolph Macon,
while Poffenberger has been consistently superb with the glove
over the early stretch of the
season.

Frosh Stickmen Split Clashes Him, Cox Sparkle
With Maryland Prep ivtrues in Spite Of Loco
After a series of unsuccessful
scrimmages, the Frosh Lacrosse
team, which travels to Friends'
School April 25, began its season
With more than indifferent success.
On Friday against a strong
Boys Latin 10, Homer Schwartz,
Al Katcef and Lauren Scheffenacker combined for 8 goals as
the Baby Blue Jays won a hard
fought 10-8 battle. Schwartz
Played a very fine game, and was
constantly in the right place at
the right time. He was frequently
on top of ground balls, and
looked as if he had been playing
lacrosse all winter. The same can
be said of Scheffnacker, whose
two goals and 1 assist were vital,
and who threw in the first goal
after only 33 seconds had elapsed
in the game.
The big surprise on attack,
however, was the work of Brady
buVal. Du Val, the third attackMan, along with Tim Roberts
and Bill Raukko, played an excellent game, much to the great
Pleasure and surprise of both the
coach and the team. He scored
Only once, but set up several
goals, and turned in two assists.
An Improved Goaly
John Beck, playing in the goal,
followed up his showing in the
Towson game with another fine
Performance.‘He had ,11 saves,
and gave x evidence of the progress that he has made since the
beginning of practice.
Bill Raukko scored the other

goal, and Tim Roberts, who
played a good, if lacklustre, game
on attack, had two assists.
The stars in the 6-4 loss to.
Severn Tuesday were the defensemen, Mike Ratner, Dave
MacCool, and Joe Hahn. Although thesa boys, like the rest
of the team in this contest, were
slow starting, and allowed Severn goals early in the periods
which enabled them to win, once
they buckled down, they were
almost impregnable, allowing
Severn just two goals in the last
30 minutes.
In this game, Scheffenacker,
who scored two goals, and
Schwartz and Katcef, who got
one apiece, were again the ofensive stalwarts. The offense,
however, was even slower starting than the defense, not getting its first tally until 4 minutes of the second period were
gone, and Severn had compiled
a 4-0 lead. It was Scheffenacker
who again initiated the scoring
with an assist from Schwartz,
who picked up 2. Timmy Roberts
gained another assist when he
aided Schwartz in the final quarter.
Some of the game statistics
are quite interesting. The first
Severn goal which was not
scored in the first two minutes
of any quarter came in the last
period when the Maroon and
White scored one with about 5
minutes gone. The series of goals
which dealt the death blow to

the Flash fledglings came in the
first minute and a half of the
second quarter when Severn
scored three times. After that,
the defense tightened up and.
Severn was held to only two
more goals for the rest of the
game, as opposed to 4 by the
young Jays.
Also interesting is the fact
that the Jays managed to outdo their opponents in almost
every important department,
both offensive and defensive. The
Jays accumulated more ground
balls, less penalties, a better
clearing percentage (which, for
the uninitiated, means that the
frosh took the ball over the
midifeld line more times, proportionately, than did their opposition), and less goalie saves. In
the big department, however,
the Jays were outdone—they lost
the game.

Odetta's appearance on

Will highlight this year's
IFC weekend.
The tickets for the Odetta
concert are $2.00, $2.25, and
$2.50 and are available at Levering Hall YMCA. Odetta is being
Jointly sponsored by the Levering YMCA and the IFC.
The IFC Formal which is being
held at the Blue Crest North
Ballroom will feature the King
Guard Orchestra. This orchestra has played under the name
Of Lester Lanin and consists of
seventeen pieces and a vocalist.
Popular Folksing-er
Odetta, a popular folksinger,
has appeared in numerous festivals and concerts and has been
featured on many television and
radio programs, including the
Belafonte Spectacular, the Ed
Sullivan Show, and the Ernie
Ford Show.
She has also appeared in concerts at Carnegie Hall and Town
Hall in New York. Recently she
had a supporting role in the
movie, "Sanctuary."
Odetta is noted for her rich
and powerful voice as well as
for the "emotional immediacy
of her singing."
Says Dougherty
According to Frank Dougherty,
President of the IFC, this year's
formal will feature service at all
of the tables by waiters. Set-ups,
Potato chips, pretzels, will all be
served free of charge.
The tables for the dance will
be arranged in "cabaret style"
complete with linen and glassware. Free parking will be available.
A highlight of the IFC Formal
Will be the awarding of keys
and the presentation of the gavel
to the new president of the IFC.

Th41 week the men of Johns

The Kennedy Administration's
pet project was initiated last
February, when Sargent Shriver,
the Corps' director, submitted a
memorandum to his brother-inlaw, the President. Mr. Shriver's
report calls for an organization

of young college graduates who
will _go abroad to teach, participate in health, agricultural,
and industrial projects, and work
in government administration.
The volunteers will be unpaid
and will not be exempt from tile
draft.

Corps, says the application,
"should have technical ability,
physical stamina and emotional

another name for the WPA. You

the world."

A second cause for complaint
was the extension of the' deadline for student council representatives. This deadline did
not extend to class officers. Thus
while petitions for class officers
were refused after the original
deadline of March 22 petitions
for student Council representatives were accepted until April
4th.
Yet another problem has
arisen over the fact that two
students ran unopposed for class
officers. Both of these boys are
members of Phi Ep and in both
cases the petitions of candidates
opposing them were 'refused.
However, in one case the opposition candidate did not have a
2.3 average, and in the second
case the candidate's petition was
turned in late. As was pointed
out above, in both of these cases
the letter of the law was observed.
General Irregularities
Two other irregularities developed in the elections concernfling Phi Ep. The first of these

was a series of posters put up
around school urging the students to vote against candidates
who were members of Phi Ep.
Following this incident two
members of Phi Sig, both of
whom were candidates for office were accused of putting
these signs up. However, to the
certain knowledge of this reporter neither of these boys was
involved.
A, B, C, D...
The final so-called scandal
occured during the elections for
freshman offices in the fall. At
this time the names on the ballot were listed out of alphabetical
order with members of Phi Ep
being listed first in some instances.
Concerning this matter David
Adams, former president of the
SC, could only state that "I
hope the ballots for this election
are in alphabetical order."
Coincidence
Assaying the entire situation,
it is evident that at this date
no actual irregularities have been
discovered. If some facts of the
election, especially those concerning Phi Ep and her alleged
control of the election committee, seem strange, we can only
ascribe it to coincidence.

Let Them Eat Cake
One begins to wonder if A. Robert Kaufman, Baltimore's omnipresent Socialist, will ever give up in his fight
to get his paper, the Young Socialist, sold on campus at
the Hopkins Bookstore. For almost a year he's been
trying. Most recently, the excuse offered by the Bookstore
for its refusal to handle Kaufman's paper, is that the Store
does not handle newspapers, Socialist or otherwise.
Just the other day, however, Kaufman again spoke
to Mr. Vayne, the Bookstore Manager, and also to WesleY
Taylor, Plant Manager, in an effort to have put on sale
in the Bookstore, the Young Socialist and two other Leftist
periodicals, the Militant and the International Socialist
Review. This time he was told "no" on the first two, but
"yes" on the International Socialist Review if this could
be furnished to the store through its usual distributor, the
Maryland News Company. According to Kaufman, this
is tantamount to refusing all three publications, because
6 the Maryland News Company doesn't handle the International Socialist Review.
Mr. Kaufman is an obnoxious person to many people
and it would be quite understandable if the Bookstore
decided not to sell his Socialist publications purely because
of Kaufman. But we have a hunch that the refusal comes
because of the contents of the Young Socialist and the
other two periodicals. And if this is so, then the Bookstore should say so, and prepare to defend itself against
the charge that the college student has a right to be
exposed to all points of view, even the most unpopular
kind espoused by Kaufman.
There were, we understand, forces in the administration, which disapproved when the YMCA presented a
high-ranking Communist official at one of its Cosmopolitan Club meetings. But the man came, spoke his piece,
and left with no great harm being done. The speech was
a poor one; not even the most liberal elements of those
attending were impressed.

By what means is this object
attainable?
Evidently by one
or two only: Either the existence
of the same passion or interest
in a majority at the same time
must be prevented, to the majority, having such co-existent
pa&sion or interest, must be rendered, by their numbers and
local situation, unable to concert
and carry into effect schemes of
oppression. If the impulse and
the opportunity be suffered to
coincide, we well know that
neither moral nor religious motives can be relied on as an
adequate control.
—James Madison

BOOM!
Today,foregoing levity,let us turn our keen young minds to the
No. 1 problem facing American colleges today: the population
explosion. Only last week four people exploded in Cleveland,
Ohio—one of them while carrying a plate of soup. In case you're
thinking Such a thing couldn't happen anywhere but in Cleveland, let me tell you there were also two other cases last week—
a 45 year old man in Provo, Utah, and a 19 year old girl in
Bangor, Maine—and in addition there was a near-miss in
Klamath Falls, Oregon—an eight year old boy who was saved
only by the quick thinking of his cat Walter who pushed the
phone off the hook with his muzzle and dialled the department
of weights and measures. (It would perhaps have made more
sense for Walter to dial the fire department, but one can hardly
expect a cat to summon a fire engine which is followed by a
Dalmatian, can one?)

I bring up the population explosion not to alarm yoti; for I
feel certain that science will ultimately solve the problem. After
all, has not science in recent years brought us such marvels as
the transistor, the computer, the bevatron, and the Marlboro
filter? Oh, what a saga of science was the discovery of the
Marlboro filter! Oh, what a heart-rending epic of endless trial
and error, of dedication and perseverance! And,in the end, what
a triumph it was when the Marlboro scientists after years of
testing and discarding one filter material after another—iron,
nickel, lead, tin, antimony,sponge cake—finally emerged, tired
but happy, from their laboratory, carrying in their hands the
perfect filter cigarette! What rejoicing there was that day!
Indeed,what rejoicing there still is whenever we light a Marlboro
and settle back and enjoy that full-flavored smoke which comes
to us in soft pack or flip-top box at tobacco counters in all
fifty states and Cleveland!
Yes,science will ultimately solve the problems rising out of the
population explosion, but in the meantime the problems hang
heavy over America's colleges. This year will bring history's
greatest rush of high school graduates. Where will we find classrooms and teachers for this gigantic new influx?
Well sir,some say the answer is to adopt the trimester system.
This system, now in use at many colleges, eliminates summer
vacations, has three semesters per annum instead of two, and
compresses a four year course into three years.
This is good,but is it good enough? Even under the trimester
system the student has occasional days off. Moreover his nights
are utterly wasted in sleeping. Is this the kind of all-out attack
that is indicated?
I say no. I say desperate problems call for desperate remedies.'I say that partial measures will not solve this crisis. I say
we must do no less than go to school every single day of the
year. But that is not all. I say we must go to school 24 hours
of every day!
The benefits of such a program are, of course, obvious. First
of all, the classroom shortage will immediately disappear because all the dormitories can be converted into classrooms.
Second,the teacher shortage will immediately disappear because
all the night watchmen can be put to work teaching calculus
and Middle English poetry. And finally, overcrowding will
immediately disappear because everyone will quit school.
Any further questions?
ED 1961 Max Shulman

The D.S.R.C. this week held an
extended debate on whether or
not to purchase laundry baskets
for the dormitory laundry.
Representative Fred Schermaker stated that he had received numerous requests for
such baskets "so that you don't
have to drag your clothes across
the floor." It was further pointed out that the baskets would
only cost 59 cents a piece.
A second representative then
inquired why "if these people are
so concerned, they don't invest
59 cents and buy it themselves."
It was finally decided that the
D.S.R.C. would purchase one
basket. This decision was also
objected to on the grounds that
"only one basket will cause friction."

unity against the administration.
But Ricci was later forced to
consider the realities of the situation and modify his stand.
In the meantime, Abernethy
consistently tried to present a
conservative platform aimed at
creating confidence in student
government by both the faculty
and administration.

Reasonable Approach
In general, one had the feeling
that the first candidate to be
asked a question chose the most
reasonable approach, and the
second candidate was forced to
somehow modify this view.
The most apparent and probably the most real difference between the two candidates occured
over the problem of the SAC.
This issue was visibly embarrassing to Ricci who was forced to
defend all aspects of the SAC
because he is currently a junior
member of the Commission.
`Morrill's Pet'
At the same time Ricci accurately stated that the SAC was
"Morrill's pet" and that the
Student Council could do nothing
about this.
But when Abernethy mentioned some of the controversial
policies of the SAC, Ricci was
forced by his position into defending the almost indefensible.
But the overall debate was
basically a failure. Anyone could

have accurately written the debate out beforehand with the exception of several of Ricci's
statements. 'All of the standard
student government problems
were discussed in their traditional style with most of the
traditional answers being given
by one candidate or the other.
New Suggestion
Perhaps the only really new
suggestion made came at the
very end of the debate. Abernethy suggested that public information campaign be .initiated
educating the dormitory residents on the problem of vandalism. As Abernethy pointed out
the $20,000 spent each year on
vandalism and destruction in the

dorms could be put to much
better use elsewhere.
Abernethy went on to state
that proctors were no solution to
the problem and their presence
in the dorm might even spur new
damage as a form of student
protest.
Valid Conclusion
It is almost impossible to reach
any valid conclusion on the basis
of this one debate. However, it is
fairly safe to make the following
statements:
Ricci was more willing to stick
his neck out if he thinks it may
win him some votes.
There was really not much
visible difference between the
candidates or their platforms.

Loyola Win
On Tuesday the varsity easily
beat their Charles Street rivals,
Loyola. Winning five of the six
singles matches, and two of the
three doubles, the Jays upped
their season record to 2-1, and to
2-0, in Mason-Dixon play. Winners for the Blue were Baron,
Brenner, Cameron, Urner, and
Farnham in singles, and UrnerBaron, and Brenner-Cameron in
doubles. Mel Lurie, in singles,
and substitutes Herb Dorsey and
Larry Garceau in doubles. were
the only people to drop points
in the match.

By IRV NATHAN
Hopkins varsity lacrosse squad,
now rated the logical favorite
for national lacrosse honors,
comes face to face with its first
large stumbling block of the
young campaign tomorrow when
it visits the University of Virginia at Charlottesville.
Off recent performances of the
top rated stick contingents in the
country, collegiate coaches have
come out with what may be
nothing more than a psychological maneuver in acclaiming the
Blue Jays the likely first place
choice. Last week's showing
against Princeton did little to
dissuade these "experts," led by
Navy's head coach Bill Bilder
back.
Playing before a screaming
throng of 2,500 partisan fans,
the Blue Jay ten demolished last
year's Ivy League champions
Princeton, 19-6, last Saturday at
Homewood. But although Hopkins exhibited tremendous power
in all areas and Coach Bob Scott
had to empty his bench to keep
the score down, there were some
mighty uneasy moments in the
first quarter for Hopkins backers.
The Jays could score but once
in the initial quarter and actually trailed 1-0 at the end of 13.35
of that period. A devestating attack, led by Roy Mayne, Jimmy
Ives, and Jerry Schmidt, soon
disspelled the fears of the crowd.
After 2.40 of the second quarter,
the score had catapulted to 5-1,
and the Blue Jays were never
headed from that point.
Howard Krongard, a traduate
of Baltimore City College, was
nothing short of spectacular in
the goal for Princeton until he
got the urge to roam and found
himself out of position on several crucial occasions. No other
Tiger distinguished himself as
the six tallies were distributed
among six Princeton stickers.

Hopkins, on the other hand,
turned in several standout performances. Mayne, a continuously improving attacker, fired six
goals and had three assists.
Schmidt assisted four times
while finding time to score twice.
And Ives, pitted in a gigantic
battle with Tim Lowery for the
third starting spot on attack,
poured in four goals and assisted twice.
Tom Biddison and Skippy Leet
scored two goals apiece to augment the prolific attack. Dick
Webster, turning in a stickout
performance, Henry ciccarone,
and Phil Sutley also chalked up
goals on the scoreboard. Sutley's
shot, the last of the day, came
after a run which carried him
the length of the field to Princeton's nets.

Statistics-wise, Hopkins again
came out the certain victor. The
Blue Jays rifled seventy-five
shots compared to thirty-seven
by the Tigers. Hopkins also led
in penalties 7-6. In the nets,
Princeton's Krongard saved 21
shots while Hopkins goalies, Jim
Greenwood and Mal Buchner,
saved a total of nine.
Virginia was not so fortunate
this past weekend as the Cavahers succumed to Maryland's
heavy attack, 14-8. The game
even Virginia's seasonal log off
at 1-1 and the Southerners
would like nothing better than
to impress stick followers at
Hopkins' expense tomorrow.
The Cavalier's biggest asset is
their attack unit, though this
fact was not prevalent last week.

Hopkins Batting Fails
Squad In 2 Contests
"The pitching is there." That's
the verdict from Hopkins baseball coach Ross Sachs after an
opening week in which he saw
his charges go down three times
—each time rebounding in a
more determined fashion from
the sting of defeat. Especially
satisfying was the come-back
performance of Soph hurler Stan
Mazanek who twirled the last
seven innings of no-hit, no-run
ball in the Jays' third loss of
the week, a 4-2 loss to RandolphMacon.
However, the big obstacle to
victory remained hitting. "We
can count on good pitching and
defense has been adequate. But
when we are going to begin to
win depends on when we start
to hit," said Sachs.
Bay State Men
Coach Sachs, during the first
week's activity also received
some fine mound-work in the
6-3 12 inning loss to MIT from
pitchers Koslowski and Kotowski,
two fellows who sound like members of an old vaudeville juggling act, but who combined for
seven shut-out innings before the
Bay State men pushed across
the winning three in the twelfth.
But the big news on the Homewood diamond was made by
Mazanek.
The promising Soph bounced
back from his portion of the
15-0 thumping Loyola administered to the Jays on opening day
to spin a nifty three hitter,

with all three safeties coming
in the first two innings. Mazanek
gave up all four runs in the first
on an error, three walks, and two
singles.
A single followed in the next
inning, but after that Mazanek
was as tough as Hopkins cafeteria meat for the Randolph
Macon batters. He walked only
one man the rest of the way.
Hopkins picked up two runs in
the sixth without a base-hit.
Catcher Bob Meyers 4th inning
single was the lone safety in a
long afternoon for Hopkins batters.
Long Afternoons
In fact, it's been a series of
long afternoons for Hopkins batters who have averaged but four
hits per game to date. Catcher
Meyers is far out in front with
four hits in twelve at bats for
a .333 mark. Meyers' fine work
behind the mask, however was
what drew the praises from HopRoss
mentor
kins' baseball
Sachs. Said Coach Sachs: "Bob
threw out one runner apiece
against Loyola and MIT. Nobody's running on him. This adds
to the confidence of our pitchers."
Coach Sachs felt the defensive
work of outfielder Mary Jones
and Leon Poffenberger also
merited special praise. Jones
contributed a sparkling diving
catch against Randolph Macon,
while Poffenberger has been consistently superb with the glove
over the early stretch of the
season.

After a series of unsuccessful
scrimmages, the Frosh Lacrosse
team, which travels to Friends'
School April 25, began its season
With more than indifferent success.
On Friday against a strong
Boys Latin 10, Homer Schwartz,
Al Katcef and Lauren Scheffenacker combined for 8 goals as
the Baby Blue Jays won a hard
fought 10-8 battle. Schwartz
Played a very fine game, and was
constantly in the right place at
the right time. He was frequently
on top of ground balls, and
looked as if he had been playing
lacrosse all winter. The same can
be said of Scheffnacker, whose
two goals and 1 assist were vital,
and who threw in the first goal
after only 33 seconds had elapsed
in the game.
The big surprise on attack,
however, was the work of Brady
buVal. Du Val, the third attackMan, along with Tim Roberts
and Bill Raukko, played an excellent game, much to the great
Pleasure and surprise of both the
coach and the team. He scored
Only once, but set up several
goals, and turned in two assists.
An Improved Goaly
John Beck, playing in the goal,
followed up his showing in the
Towson game with another fine
Performance.‘He had ,11 saves,
and gave x evidence of the progress that he has made since the
beginning of practice.
Bill Raukko scored the other

goal, and Tim Roberts, who
played a good, if lacklustre, game
on attack, had two assists.
The stars in the 6-4 loss to.
Severn Tuesday were the defensemen, Mike Ratner, Dave
MacCool, and Joe Hahn. Although thesa boys, like the rest
of the team in this contest, were
slow starting, and allowed Severn goals early in the periods
which enabled them to win, once
they buckled down, they were
almost impregnable, allowing
Severn just two goals in the last
30 minutes.
In this game, Scheffenacker,
who scored two goals, and
Schwartz and Katcef, who got
one apiece, were again the ofensive stalwarts. The offense,
however, was even slower starting than the defense, not getting its first tally until 4 minutes of the second period were
gone, and Severn had compiled
a 4-0 lead. It was Scheffenacker
who again initiated the scoring
with an assist from Schwartz,
who picked up 2. Timmy Roberts
gained another assist when he
aided Schwartz in the final quarter.
Some of the game statistics
are quite interesting. The first
Severn goal which was not
scored in the first two minutes
of any quarter came in the last
period when the Maroon and
White scored one with about 5
minutes gone. The series of goals
which dealt the death blow to

the Flash fledglings came in the
first minute and a half of the
second quarter when Severn
scored three times. After that,
the defense tightened up and.
Severn was held to only two
more goals for the rest of the
game, as opposed to 4 by the
young Jays.
Also interesting is the fact
that the Jays managed to outdo their opponents in almost
every important department,
both offensive and defensive. The
Jays accumulated more ground
balls, less penalties, a better
clearing percentage (which, for
the uninitiated, means that the
frosh took the ball over the
midifeld line more times, proportionately, than did their opposition), and less goalie saves. In
the big department, however,
the Jays were outdone—they lost
the game.
